work.p: This manuscript relates to the poem first published as "After All, Not to Create Only" in newspapers and then as a small book with the same title in 1871. The poem was ultimately titled "Song of the Exposition." This manuscript is a draft of lines 51-53 in the final version of the poem.

This manuscript relates to the poem first published as "After All, Not to Create Only" in 1871. The poem was ultimately titled "Song of the Exposition." This manuscript seems to be related to what became section 8 in the final version of the poem.

This manuscript relates to the poem first published as "After All, Not to Create Only" in 1871. The poem was ultimately titled "Song of the Exposition." This manuscript seems to be thematically related to what became section 1 in the final version of the poem.
This manuscript relates to the poem first published as "After All, Not to Create Only" in 1871. The poem was ultimately titled "Song of the Exposition."

This is a draft of lines from a poem first published as "After All, Not to Create Only" in 1871. The poem was ultimately titled "Song of the Exposition." This manuscript is a draft of lines 206-209 in the final version of the poem.

This manuscript contains notes toward a poem first published as "After All, Not to Create Only" in 1871. The poem was ultimately titled "Song of the Exposition." This manuscript relates to section 8 in the final version of the poem.

This manuscript contains a drafted line of a poem published as "After All, Not to Create Only" first in newspapers and then as a book with the same title in 1871. The poem was ultimately titled "Song of the Exposition." This manuscript relates to line 39 in the final version of Leaves of Grass.

This manuscript relates to the poem first published as "After All, Not to Create Only" and ultimately entitled "Song of the Exposition." This manuscript seems to have a loose relationship to what became section 5 in the final version of Leaves of Grass.

This manuscript relates to the poem first published as "After All, Not to Create Only" and ultimately entitled "Song of the Exposition." This manuscript seems to have a loose relationship to what became section 8 in the final version of Leaves of Grass.

availability.p: Copyright © 2001 by Ed Folsom and Kenneth M. Price, all rights reserved. Items in the Archive may be shared in accordance with the Fair Use provisions of U.S. copyright law. Redistribution or republication on other terms, in any medium, requires express written consent from the editors and advance notification of the publisher, The Institure for Advanced Technology in the Humanities. Permission to reproduce the graphic images in this archive has been granted by the owners of the originals for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: This manuscript was probably written in 1871 after Whitman accepted the invitation from the American Institute to compose and recite a poem at the opening of its fortieth Annual Exhibition in New York City. Whitman read the poem on September 7, 1871, and it was published on that date in the New York Evening Post and on subsequent days in at least eight other newspapers.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: After All Not to Create Only
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.
bibl.note: Transcribed from a digital image of the original manuscript taken by Brett Barney with a hand-held digital camera.

div1.head: After all, not to create but to finish enlarge obey,
div1.l: After all, not to create, but to finish enlarge obey,

Not to destroy, but re-vivify
and enlarge, and enlarge and improve & carry forward, is the mis-
sionmission of the New World.

After all, is there, can there
be any New World?

To accept what is already founded,
and bring it hither,

To adopt, give it our own nativity,
popular, modern, to obey as well as command

To save and enlarge, to follow
as well as lead more than to lead, —to obey as well as command,
These also are the lessons of the
To revivify and work

To rehabilitate in free it advance it,& to use & power
and vastness p yet previously

After all, not to lead only, but to lead,
but as much, or more,
to follow,

Not to originate only create, or destroy only,
but more to adopt and, continue,

To engraft adopt improve accept,enlarge and free
is may be the lesson of the
New World:

And While after all how little
is truly really the New—how
much is the Old, Old World,

After all, less to create than
we thought,

Still less to destroy, is the
mission of the New World here—
Not to

After all, lo ess to really actually create,
than we thought than I thought

Still less to destroy, is the our
New World's mission

And more to grow the f
ripe fruits

Ever to reap the harvest of the past
and give to the vast
accumulations form
& use
Not to
To adapt, resuscitate
The main things are all here

After all, less than we thought
either to create or destroy
Indeed, after all indeed is there any New World

born Daughter

After all, is there,—
Can there be any
New World?

Long, long, long has the grass
been growing,

Long and long has the rain been
falling,

Long has the globe been rolling
round.

While how much indeed, how much
of is really the New?—how
much the Old, Old World?

After all, not to lead only,
but to follow,

Not to found but to carry to continue
forward & perfect what is already
founded—to accept, ing continue enlarge ing
and free, ing all,

Not to command only, but as
much, or more, to obey—
is the lesson of the New World.

While how little is really the
New—how much is the
Old, Old World!

Mother majestic! America! round thee, to-day
thy serried ranks of giants, offspring,
quintupled circling circle to-day,

Their heads, forms Towering,—yet with
her, thee ela above all
towering

Law upon thy right.

div1.head: After all, not to create or destroy only
div1.l:
After all, not to create or
destroy only, nor to found only,

To But to see clearly bring hither what is already
founded, hither and bring it hither,
and appreciate it,
To give it our own identity, popular, modern,

To free and advance it to uses, and beauty
and vastness & power previously unknown

To obey as well as command—to follow, more
than to lead,

These also are the lessons too may be the missions of the New
World:
